s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Use the SQL language to define, query and manipulate a relational database.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Understand query processing and optimization, transaction and security management in a relational database management system.

s2: Apply conceptual database modelling methods such as entity-relationship model to design a relational database.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Understand the state of the art of database management systems, and big data management challenges (Amazon's Dynamo, Google's BigTable, MongoDB and MapReduce).

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: The topics include the relational data model, SQL, entity-relationship model, functional dependencies, (de-)normalisation, relational algebra, query processing and optimisation, database transactions and security.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: Apply database design methods on functional dependencies and normal forms to evaluate the quality of a relational database design.

s2: Describe the basic concepts of the relational model and understand its mathematical foundation;

s2: To deepen the understanding of relational databases, the current industry development of database systems such as NoSQL databases will be introduced at the end of this course.

s1: This course takes a detailed look at the services provided by, and the internals of, an existing operating system to see how each part is constructed and integrated into the whole.
s2: This course is an introduction to relational databases and the general skills for designing and using them.

s1: The lectures will also address recent literature describing advances in operating systems.

s1: The following topics are addressed: system programming and its facilities (including I/O, signals, job control, interprocess communication, sockets, transport layers, remote operations), system calls and their relation to the system libraries, process management and coordination, implementation of message passing, memory management, interrupt handling, real-time clocks, device-independent input/output, serial-line drivers, network communication, disk drivers, deadlock avoidance, scheduling paradigms, file systems, security.
s2: Use the SQL language to define, query and manipulate a relational database.

s2: Describe the basic concepts of the relational model and understand its mathematical foundation;
